definitions: practice a play, speech, or musical performance repeatedly to prepare for public presentation
recite or repeat something from memory in order to remember it better
examples: The actors rehearsed the final scene multiple times today
We need to rehearse every movement before opening night
Students rehearsed their multiplication tables before the test
She rehearsed the important points in her mind repeatedly

definitions: hold royal office and rule as king or queen over a territory
be the dominant or most powerful force in a particular area or situation
examples: Queen Elizabeth II reigned for over seventy years
The emperor reigned during a period of great prosperity
Confusion reigned in the office after the announcement
Peace reigned throughout the valley for many decades

definitions: repay money to someone who has spent it on your behalf or for your purposes
examples: The company will reimburse your travel expenses next week
They reimbursed me for the damaged goods immediately

definitions: check or control a horse by pulling on its reins
keep under control or within limits through deliberate restraint
examples: She reined her horse to a complete stop
The rider reined the stallion back from galloping
You need to rein in your spending this month
The manager tried to rein in the team's enthusiasm

definitions: strengthen or support a structure with additional material or bracing
strengthen or support an idea, feeling, or pattern through repetition or emphasis
examples: Engineers reinforced the bridge with steel cables yesterday
Workers reinforced the walls before the hurricane arrived
These results reinforce our initial hypothesis about climate change
Parents should reinforce positive behavior with praise and rewards

definitions: restore someone to their former position or rank after removal or suspension
examples: The court ordered the company to reinstate the fired employee
They reinstated him as team captain after the investigation

definitions: restore someone or something to unity or wholeness by integration into a group or system
examples: The program helps reintegrate former prisoners into society successfully
Therapists work to reintegrate traumatic memories into conscious awareness

definitions: interpret something again or in a new or different way from previous understanding
examples: Scholars reinterpreted the ancient texts using modern linguistic methods
The director reinterpreted Shakespeare's play for contemporary audiences

definitions: bring something back into use or existence after it had been absent or discontinued
examples: The government plans to reintroduce wolves into the national park
The company reintroduced the popular product after customer demands

definitions: change something so much that it appears entirely new and different
create or design something again in a completely new way
examples: She reinvented herself after moving to a new city
The company needs to reinvent its business model completely
They reinvented the traditional recipe with modern techniques
Artists constantly reinvent classic themes in contemporary works

definitions: give new energy, strength, or vitality to something that had become weak or inactive
examples: The new CEO's vision reinvigorated the struggling company completely
Fresh investment reinvigorated the local economy within six months

definitions: make a product or publication available again after it had been discontinued
examples: The record label reissued the classic album on vinyl
The publisher reissued her novels with new cover designs

definitions: say something again or repeatedly, typically for emphasis or clarity of understanding
examples: The teacher reiterated the importance of studying for finals
Let me reiterate our position on this critical issue

definitions: refuse to accept, consider, or submit to something or someone
dismiss as inadequate, unacceptable, or faulty after examination or consideration
examples: The committee rejected all three proposals without explanation
She rejected his marriage proposal after careful consideration
The body rejected the transplanted organ despite medication
Quality control rejected the defective products before shipping

definitions: feel or show great joy, happiness, or triumph about something
examples: The whole nation rejoiced when the war finally ended
Parents rejoiced at the safe return of their children

definitions: return to and become part of a group or organization after leaving
say something quick and often sharp or witty in reply to a remark
examples: She rejoined the company after her maternity leave ended
The soldiers rejoined their unit after completing special training
'That's your opinion,' he rejoined with obvious irritation
She rejoined that the plan was completely impractical

definitions: make someone or something look or feel younger, fresher, or more lively
give new energy or vigor to something that had become tired or ineffective
examples: A good night's sleep rejuvenated her completely
The spa treatment rejuvenated his tired muscles effectively
The new investment rejuvenated the declining neighborhood significantly
Fresh ideas rejuvenated the stagnant corporate culture quickly

definitions: light a fire again after it has gone out
revive or renew an emotion, relationship, or interest that had faded
examples: He rekindled the campfire with dry twigs and paper
They rekindled the dying embers before going to sleep
The reunion rekindled their old friendship after twenty years
The documentary rekindled public interest in the case

definitions: return to a former worse state after a period of improvement, especially in illness
examples: The patient relapsed after stopping her medication too early
He relapsed into addiction after six months of sobriety

definitions: give an account of or tell the story of events or experiences
establish or show a connection or relationship between things
feel sympathy with or identify with someone's experiences or feelings
examples: She related the entire incident to the police officers
The witness related what he had seen that night
Scientists relate these symptoms to vitamin D deficiency
The report relates crime rates to poverty levels
Many teenagers can relate to the main character's struggles
I really relate to what you're going through

definitions: become or make someone become less tense, anxious, or stressed
make rules, restrictions, or controls less strict or severe
examples: She relaxed by the pool after a stressful week
The massage helped relax his tense shoulder muscles
The government relaxed immigration rules for skilled workers
Schools relaxed their dress code during summer months

definitions: receive and pass on information or a message to another person
receive and transmit signals or broadcasts electronically to extend their range
examples: Please relay this message to the team immediately
She relayed the instructions to everyone in the building
The satellite relays television signals across the continent
Radio towers relay emergency broadcasts during disasters

definitions: allow or enable someone or something to escape from confinement or control
make something available to the public for the first time
stop holding something and allow it to move, act, or flow freely
examples: The zoo released the rehabilitated eagle into the wild
Authorities released the prisoner after new evidence emerged
The studio will release the movie next Friday nationwide
The company released its quarterly earnings report yesterday
She released her grip on the rope slowly
The valve releases pressure when it gets too high

definitions: assign to a lower or less important position, rank, or status than before
examples: The team was relegated to the second division this season
They relegated him to a minor role after the merger

definitions: abandon or soften a harsh intention or cruel treatment after persistent pressure
examples: The storm finally relented after three days of rain
She relented and allowed the children extra playtime

definitions: cause pain, distress, or difficulty to become less severe or serious
take over duties from someone else to give them rest
free someone from an unpleasant feeling, burden, or situation
examples: This medication relieves headaches within thirty minutes
Massage therapy relieves muscle tension and stress effectively
The night nurse relieved her colleague at midnight
Fresh troops relieved the exhausted soldiers at dawn
Talking about it relieved her anxiety considerably
The loan relieved them of immediate financial pressure

definitions: voluntarily cease to keep or claim something; give up possession or control
examples: He relinquished control of the company to his daughter
She reluctantly relinquished her claim to the property

definitions: enjoy or appreciate something greatly and with evident satisfaction or pleasure
examples: She relished every moment of her vacation in Paris
He relished the opportunity to prove his critics wrong

definitions: experience something again in one's imagination or memory, especially vividly
examples: She relived the accident in her nightmares every night
He relived his championship victory through old video recordings

definitions: put ammunition into a weapon again or load something again after use
examples: The soldier quickly reloaded his rifle during combat
You need to reload the page to see new updates

definitions: move to a new place and establish one's home or business there
examples: The company relocated its headquarters to downtown Seattle
Many families relocated after the hurricane destroyed their homes

definitions: depend on with full trust or confidence for support, help, or supply
examples: Small businesses rely heavily on local customer support
You can always rely on her to keep secrets

definitions: continue to exist or be in the same state or condition
stay in the same place or position rather than leaving
examples: The mystery remains unsolved after twenty years of investigation
She remained calm despite the dangerous situation
Please remain seated until the plane stops completely
Only three students remained after class to ask questions

definitions: sell books at a reduced price when they are no longer selling well
examples: The publisher remaindered thousands of unsold copies last month
Bookstores often remainder titles after the holiday season

definitions: make something again or differently, especially a movie or song
examples: Hollywood remade the classic film with modern special effects
She remade the dress to fit her daughter perfectly

definitions: place a defendant on bail or in custody while awaiting trial
examples: The judge remanded the suspect in custody until trial
The court remanded him on bail for two weeks

definitions: say something as a comment or observation about something noticed
examples: She remarked that the weather was unusually warm today
Several guests remarked on the beautiful flower arrangements

definitions: marry again after being divorced or after one's spouse has died
examples: She remarried two years after her husband's death
He never remarried after the divorce was finalized

definitions: rectify or cure an undesirable situation, problem, or illness effectively
examples: The new policy should remedy the current housing shortage
This treatment remedies most cases of vitamin deficiency

definitions: have in or be able to bring to one's mind awareness of past events
bear in mind and not forget to do something important
examples: I remember meeting her at the conference last year
She couldn't remember where she left her keys
Remember to lock the door when you leave tonight
Please remember that the meeting starts at nine

definitions: cause someone to remember something or someone they might have forgotten
examples: She reminded him about his doctor's appointment tomorrow morning
This photo reminds me of our vacation in Greece

definitions: indulge in enjoyable recollection of past events, often with others
examples: The old friends reminisced about their college days together
She loves to reminisce about her travels through Europe

definitions: send money in payment for goods or services or as a gift
cancel or refrain from exacting or inflicting a debt or punishment
examples: Please remit payment within thirty days of receiving invoice
She remitted the funds to her family overseas
The judge remitted part of the fine due to circumstances
The governor remitted his sentence to life imprisonment

definitions: change the structure, form, or appearance of something, especially a building
examples: They remodeled their kitchen with modern appliances last year
The company remodeled its entire office space recently

definitions: get on a horse, bicycle, or motorcycle again after getting off
produce or stage a play or exhibition again after an interval
examples: The rider remounted his horse after the brief rest
She remounted her bike and continued the race
The theater company remounted the popular play this season
They remounted the exhibition due to public demand

definitions: take something away or off from the position occupied
eliminate or get rid of something unwanted or dismiss from position
examples: Please remove your shoes before entering the temple
Workers removed all the old furniture from the office
The board voted to remove the CEO from office
Surgery successfully removed the tumor from her lung

definitions: give a new name to someone or something that already has a name
examples: They renamed the street after the civil rights leader
The company renamed itself to reflect its new direction

definitions: cause someone or something to be in a particular state or condition
provide or give a service, help, or information formally
perform or present an artistic work or translate into another language
process an image or animation digitally to produce final visual output
examples: The accident rendered him unable to walk for months
The storm rendered thousands of people homeless overnight
The jury rendered its verdict after three days deliberation
The accountant rendered professional services to the company
The pianist rendered Chopin's nocturne with great sensitivity
She rendered the ancient text into modern English
The computer renders the 3D animation in real time
This software renders high-quality video extremely quickly

definitions: abandon one's loyalty or principles and become a rebel or outlaw
examples: Several soldiers renegaded and joined the rebel forces
He renegaded from his political party after disagreements

definitions: negotiate again in order to change the terms of an agreement
examples: The union wants to renegotiate the contract for better wages
They renegotiated their mortgage to get lower interest rates
